body: [This is why we can't have nice things](http://www.felixcloutier.com/x86/MOVAPS.html)
cc @tqchen for review.
Thanks for catching this. Would you like to make a PR to fix this?
@siju-samuel @kazum Welcome for review

> @stilistik can you add Equal and NotEqual operators as well?
Featured in my latest commit

Some other points

1. We should upload some pre-tuned parameters for resnet and delete the old records in x86/conv2d.py

2. In terms of graph level tuner. We should think about the formalization introduced by the paper we discussed in  #1585 .
Currently we have different implementations for x86 cpu and arm cpu. Specifically, we have spatial pack, NCHWc_common, NCHWc_1x1 and winograd. On both x86 and arm, each of them has the chance to be the best for some input shapes. So the optimal solution is to merge the templates for x86 and arm cpu, and let the graph tuner choose them by considering both kernel time and layout transform time.
Your current graph tuner only supports NCHWc template. Do you think it is easy to generalize it to support arbitrary templates? I think this can improve the performance a lot at least on arm cpu. And the framework will be quite generalizable since we can add many templates and let the graph tuner make the final optimal solution.
I have address the feedback and I think it is pretty good. Can anyone give some review? I would like to merge it soon so I can use it to help debug reverse mode ad.

Graph tuner supports general schedule template. The key point is to define how to generate layout transformation given a schedule template. For now I just add built-in layout transform generator for NCHWc, but it is not hard to add support for other formats.

I agree that we should finally tune different algorithms, The key part is still managing possible layout transforms between given schedules, which might come from different algorithms.

In terms of problem formulation, I would like to treat it more related to solver. For PBQP solver, we may want to formulate it as graph and cost matrices. For DP or RL methods, it might be more suitable to use states/actions representation. Current design is base class converts records from autotvm and manages fundamental data structure. In specific solver, these data structures are used to formulate the problem in a way suitable for this solver. What do you think about this way? In current graph tuner implementation, there is some information specific to DP solver in base class. I'll refactor and move them under DPExecutor.
Great! noticed the added `Send+Sync`. This should be good to go then.

Thanks @zhiics 

Yes, different PR after with Fallback mechanism followed by integrating it to TVM build makes easy to understand the end to end flow while review.

> When the source or destination operand is a memory operand, the operand must be aligned on a 16-byte (128-bit version), 32-byte (VEX.256 encoded version) or 64-byte (EVEX.512 encoded version) boundary or a general-protection exception (#GP) will be generated.

For parallel lambdas which use a temporal workspace, LLVM will emit `load`/`store` instructions which specify an alignment e.g.,
```llvm
  %70 = getelementptr inbounds float, float* %4, i64 %69
  %71 = bitcast float* %70 to <8 x float>*
  store <8 x float> %68, <8 x float>* %71, align 32, !tbaa !149
```
where `%4` is the temporal workspace.
The llvm ops get translated into `MOVAPS` which `#GP` when when the workspace has the wrong alignment.
This sounds like a bug to me in the parallel code generator(or the workspace allocator)which do not respect the alignment requirements
Specially, we do require temporal workspace also align to a minimum alignment and the compiler takes advantage of that

> sounds like a bug to me in the parallel code generator(or the workspace allocator)

Yes, this was most definitely a bug in my implementation of the workspace allocator. It's fixed now, so threading works in the rust runtime. Figuring this out required bisecting the generated llvm code with debugging statements, which isn't the best developer experience, but I suppose this is unavoidable.
Gotcha, maybe we should put a heavy comment on workspace and DeviceAPI interface to warn this potential issue to the developers. This is certainly something that I would have overlooked as well

~PR incoming!~ Actually, it literally says right there in `c_backend_api.h`:

```c
/*!
 * \brief Backend function to allocate temporal workspace.
 *
 * \note The result allocate spaced is ensured to be aligned to kTempAllocaAlignment.
 *
 * ...
 */
```

This is totally my fault.
Thanks @srkreddy1238 @nishi-t

Thanks for contributing this! I have made a few review comments

re: general Unification no longer holds. I intentionally leave that because I kind of do not like the previous way of handling general unification. 

Specifically:
-  I was hoping that when we try to Unify, ```Tuple(?A, ?B) == Tuple(?C, 1)``` it should return a new incomplete type ```?t```, who have a new constraint ```?t = Tuple(?A, ? B)``` and ```?A ==?C ```
- The goal is to always make sure that the types in the system are either Incomplete, in which case it can be solved by relations or concrete and avoid cases where there is a composite type of incomplete ones.
- The main advantage here is that it would allow the data structure to perfectly trigger a set of relation functions when a new type is resolved.
Avoiding nested incomplete types sounds like a good way to reduce headaches

Type inference requires that we unify partial types, without it we don't have type inference. I feel like we keep trying to change the algorithm in ways which changes it from something that is not inference.

The whole point of doing type inference is that the constraints which cause a type to be complete are scattered throughout the program and won't manifest at a single use site, and are recursive by nature.

The reason type inference algorithms use union find is to manage the number of constraints generated and decompose them into the minimal number of primitive constraints between types, which may further give rise to other constraints. 

The first solution is exactly what happens under the previous algorithm, except yours introduces an unneeded variable, we don't need a fresh `?t` at all anything that unifies with `Tuple(?A, ?B)` must be `Tuple(_, _)` and this transitively holds even with a fresh variable.

Even when you have a complete inference algorithm the solution may be under constrained and you  can end up with a composite type containing incomplete types, if you are not OK with this then you don't want type inference.

For example there is a bug in the current inferencer which can not be resolved without supporting nested incomplete types. 

When checking a call we must unify the type of the node with a function type of the form `(T_1, ..., T_N) -> R` where `N` is the number of arguments, without this behavior we can't support polymorphism where there is an outer constructor wrapping the type argument.

To be clear, I am all for supporting Unifying the composite types with incomplete types. But just think a second PR is necessary to sort that out.

My main point is to introduce a fresh incomplete type ```?T``` for handling composite incomplete types like```Tuple(?A, ? B)``` . With the following reasons:

- The current algorithm tries to implement a fast version of inference that does lazy triggers of the active relations in the bipartite graph
- Specifically, when a Type get updated by the solver, all the unsolved relations that refer to the Type will get triggered.
- However, to make sure such relation propagates nicely, we will need to allocate a node for each type that is incomplete, say a relation which relies on a Tuple(?A, ? B), which is compositional. If there is no node in the bipartite graph to represent this type, then the triggering is flawed.
   - Conceptually, when a composite type contains incomplete holes, we can also view it as a constraint between ?T and ?A, ?B if we generate a fresh ```?T```, and the relation is ```MakeTupleRelation(?A, ?B, ?T)```
- The main concern I have is when the inference gets ties into symbolic integers, in this case, actually, the symbolic integer itself can be incomplete, which means TensorType is a composite type instead of a primitive one, having a strict rule such that incomplete type composition is always represented by relation might help mitigate this issue.

Given these thoughts, I feel it is better to bring a second PR to solve these issues. Note that the original way of treating incomplete composite type solves the issue of composite tuples but not the symbolic integer case. I hope we can check in things that are clean, limited but known to work on limited cases, then improve them to cover a broader set of things that we care about.

### Example to Illustrate the problem.
Imagine we have relation
```
- R1(1, ?B)
- R2(?B, ?E)
- R3(Tuple(?B, ?E), ?C)
```
When we call R1 to update ?B into a concrete type, R2 will be triggered, because ```?B``` have maintains a list of pending relations on it which includes R2. It is harder to tell whether we should trigger R3(we need to maintain the reverse depending by unpacking the tuple recursively), because although B is concrete, E is still not solved.

A better way would be storing things as(which I am arguing for)
```
- R1(1, ?B)
- R2(?B, ?E)
- MakeTupleRelation(?B, ?E, ?T)
- R3(?T, ?C)
```
In this case, E will R1 will trigger MakeTupleRelation, which will fail, then once ?E get updated, it will trigger MakeTupleRelation again. Or we can enhance the solver to be aware of that any only trigger when things are concrete.

The potential drawback of introducing intermediate type though is that when we are trying to unify two tuple types, they don't necessarily propagate to the relation in the child. For example 
```
Tuple(?A, 1) == Tuple(2, ?B)
```
will reduce to ```?A == 2 and ?B == 1```, but if they are expanded as relations, it becomes
```
- ?T1 == ?T2
- MakeTupleRelation(?A, 1, T1)
- MakeTupleRelation(2, ?B, T2)
```
Special rules are necessary to detect duplicated MakeTupleRelation in this case and propagates the constraints to the child equivalence (?A == 2) and (?B == 1).

The index here is not really array index, but index within a computational graph. It is unlikely that we will build a graph with more than billions of nodes, so it is not necessary in this case. The array indexing and shape are already using int64
Can we move most of the discussion to this issue instead? and post RFC here
CC @dmlc/tvm-team

The main point we want to address is how to print the code in graph form (without all the lets). This is important because most people construct their net in this way. As an example, we could have

```
add(%x, add(%y, %z))
```

but a preferred way of printing it should be
```
%1 = add(%y, %z)
%2 = add(%x, %1)
```

@jroesch I tried to address most of your comments. I feel the code could need another small refactor once we introduced a span based reporting with real error message model. I have added comments to state that the current version intentionally left out compositional type resolving for a future PR. 

The current part is sufficient for moving forward with simple type checking, while leaving room for future enhancements to TypeSolver without changing the interface

> how to print the code in graph form

Out of curiosity, what's wrong with `let`s? The line per assign is easy to debug and parse. If a user wanted to visualize the graph, the Relay IR can be lowered to graphviz or revered in Tensorboard. Since everything has a unique name, it'll be easy to jump back and forth.
@junrushao1994 can you also help review this?

I just feel there is a tension that user still starts with the old habit of constructing things via DSL(graph form), which makes them cluttered in that case. The printer need to print out the program faithfully still in this case without having to generate a long line of nested calls
Let us move the discussion to the corresponding RFC issue. @joshpoll can you cross post the proposal there and use the PR to mainly comment on implementation details?

cross posting.
We will need a spec on how nested expressions can be printed, 

specifically, instead of 
```
add(%x, add(%y, %z))
```

We prefer
```
%1 = add(%y, %z)
%2 = add(%x, %1)
```

Note that add will become neural network layers such as conv2d etc. When we construct the exprs, it is quite typical that the expression is already CSEed. Example:

```
%1 = add(%y, %z)
%2 = add(%1, %1)
```

I think there will be such 'special case' for every type constructor (reference, tuple, function, tensor).
Can we see the solver as having two separate part: a traditional algol-w union find, and a type relation solver?
While it seems more ad hoc, IMO adding a bunch of special case is worse.
Another reason is we probably need a fancier type inference algorithm, as we are system f, but is currently using algol w - it only work to hindley milner, so first class forall (basically virtual template) cannot get typed. Or we should change our doc to clarify that we are hm.

> The main point we want to address is how to print the code in graph form (without all the lets). This is important because most people construct their net in this way. As an example, we could have
> 
> ```
> add(%x, add(%y, %z))
> ```
> but a preferred way of printing it should be
> 
> ```
> %1 = add(%y, %z)
> %2 = add(%x, %1)
> ```

I am a bit confused. doesnt the lower code has two let?

I think we can view it by seeing two kind of let: %1 is the 'explicit let', which map to relay let.
_1 is the 'implicit let', which does not map to relay concept, only to denote whenever _1 is refered, the rhs is used (and shared).

Also to be frank, I do not see a reason to has relay program as graph - we still need let because we have scope and effect(no reference for now, but there is general recursion), we cant see graph as tree (because exponential blowup), and we still need to handle binding as we has let, so we are getting the benefit of neither world.

I had made some facility to automatically turn binder into value (LFunctor), so with it we can operate a tree as graph without actually having one, so I think we should at least sit down and revisit why we want graph right now (we can always add it later).
I address the review posed by jared, and add a lot of test case. can anyone give one last round of review?

I don't think this concern is within the scope of this issue/PR. IMO the pretty printer should print the AST exactly as it's presented. I think it's too restrictive to force function arguments to be values at parse time, and thus we must allow for nested expressions. We could possibly have a compiler option that forces certain compiler passes like ANF and CSE before printing or even use the pretty printer to reformat code into "graph" style.

This is an issue because this is how user usually constructs a program via DSL, and we need to make sure when we print, they are print out in a well-defined compact fashion which is readable by the parser(without running any transformation pass). The graph itself is not a graph for the exactly the same reason that it is already CSed as user constructs them.

i.e. if a user constructs the program via DSL(i.e. IRBuilder), she might write
```python
x = some relay_expr
y = relay.op.add(x, 1)
let z = relay.op.add(y, y)
```
If we simply print out the expression as they are, it will explode as a tree
```
let %z = add(add(%x, 1), add(%x, 1))
``` 
The information that the intermediate value is CSEd is missing here, instead, a better way would be 
```
%1 = add(%x, 1)
let %z = add(%1, %1)
``` 

I understand this is normally not considered as good pratice for normal programs, but this makes sense for deep learning workloads, where each operations can be arbitrarily nested.

Most users still think in terms of computational graphs, and it is important for us to support that concept well.

Thanks for the contribution. I have gone through the code. The key challenge here as raised in the #1756 is that certain part of code will require platform dependent API, specifically:

## API specificity

- Fork system call
   - Only supported in linux, there is windows equivalent, not supported by andoir
- filesys dir query
   - Current implementation linux only, it is possible to get a windows/linux compatible version
- socket related things
   - select API is relatively linux, however, we can port a windows/linux compatible select from https://github.com/dmlc/rabit/blob/master/src/socket.h#L423

## Where to put the code
The general principle is everything under src/runtime need to be stable and works on all systems, the ```apps/cpp_rpc``` would be more relaxed, and make use of APIs like fork.

Given the current status of the code, I would recommend to encapsulate the RPCServer as a class and put most of the listen, accept and filesystem logic into ```apps/cpp_rpc``` first.  Ideally, I would  recommend to make it windows and linux compatible, but this is not a must as python version of rpc server can still be used.

There are still value to put certain code into src/runtime/rpc, specifically the tracker reporting logic, if we can encapsulate that as a class e.g. (TrackerClient) and encapsulate certain reporting feature there, we could put some of the tracker related logic into there.

Just one question, could we not set NCHW(x)c to NCHW4c explicitly but give it to AutoTVM decide how to split input channel?  Then we do handle NCHW(x)c, not NCHW4c specially. For example, we have _contrib_conv2d_NCHWc to handle it.
I think the original code is fine and since they are forwarded in a different function body, it does not count as double forwarding
let me try to crash it

@FrozenGene yes we could let AutoTVM to tune the input channel split factor. But this will need some change in `alter_conv2d_layout` and some extra layout transform will be needed. I think this will be a good idea when we have graph tuner. Actually, I have tried x = 4/8/16 on all resnet layers, and found that perf of 4 > 8 > 16.

@vinx13 Yes. Your data layout is one special case of NCHW(x)c and set it be 4 based on Resnet model benchmark. However, If we use it on another models, how do we make sure 4 is the best choice? So this is the reason I raise the question before. On AutoTVM x86, it walks on another road to achieve it: https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1772/files I prefer it more. It doesn't set one number manually.
@merrymercy https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/topi/tests/python/test_topi_conv2d_nchw.py#L79 Looks like this test creates x86 conv2d decl but getting arm conv2d schedule from tophub.
A quick question: is it intended that this doc is not included in `docs/dev/index.rst`? I have to use search to find the doc...

Re-triggering the CI: test_topi_matmul.test_matmul is flaky (See http://ci.tvm.ai:8080/blue/organizations/jenkins/tvm/detail/PR-1788/1/pipeline).

Related issue: #1784

A side note: It is undefined behavior to `exit -1` in shells. Exit code should be unsigned int in `[0, 255]`. (http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/7990989775/xcu/chap2.html#tag_001_014_007)

I noticed that this problem occurs every time when CI fails, so is it intended to return an undefined error code?

It seems to me a threshold issue. Currently in `test_matmul`, we have `atol = 0` and `rtol = 0`. And the numpy's `assert_allclose` uses `atol + rtol * abs(desired)` as the threshold, so when `abs(desired)` is pretty small, and `atol = 0`, the threshold can be relatively small compared with numerical precision.

Ref: https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.testing.assert_allclose.html
